In other cases, however, different image sensor integration times may be applied for two or more of the frames capture during the burst.

In one example, each burst may include three captured frames (e.g., sub-exposures). Each of the three captured frames at a 30 Hz overall capture rate may be associated with a different integration time. For example, a first capture sub-exposure frame may have an integration time of 15 ms, a second may have an integration time of 1 ms, and a third may have an integration time of 0.1 ms. As the integration time is reduced, so may be the captured brightness of the light source. By detecting the brightness level of a particular light source in each captured sub-exposure and comparing the detected brightness level to the associated integration times, the actual light level of the light source may be determined. For example, the detected brightness levels may be scaled using 256 bits and then may be normalized in time to provide the actual light level of the detected light source.

The sub-exposures included in an image capture burst may be useful beyond determining actual light level of a light source. For example, any of the burst sub-exposures may be used as a captured image provided to the primary image capture stream or to the secondary image capture stream. That is, in situations where an image capture event associated with the primary image capture stream would result in an image sensor integration time window overlapping with the integration time needed for an image capture event scheduled for the secondary image capture stream, then an earlier frame in the burst or a later frame in the burst may be used for the primary or secondary image capture stream to avoid the potential conflict.

FIG. 15 is a flowchart showing an example process 1500 for navigating a vehicle, consistent with the disclosed embodiments. Process 1500 may be performed by at least one processing device of a host vehicle, such as processing unit 110, as described above. It is to be understood that throughout the present disclosure, the term “processor” is used as a shorthand for “at least one processor.” In other words, a processor may include one or more structures (e.g., circuitry) that perform logic operations whether such structures are collocated, connected, or disbursed. In some embodiments, a non-transitory computer readable medium may contain instructions that when executed by a processor cause the processor to perform process 1500. Further, process 1500 is not necessarily limited to the steps shown in FIG. 15, and any steps or processes of the various embodiments described throughout the present disclosure may also be included in process 1500, including those described above with respect to, for example. FIGS. 12, 13, and 14.

In step 1510, process 1500 includes receiving a plurality of images acquired by a camera onboard the host vehicle. For example, step 1510 may include receiving images captured using camera 1210 described above. Accordingly, the plurality of images may be received via a first channel and via a second channel, such as channels 1222 and 1232, respectively. In some embodiments, the first channel and the second channel may be associated with different electrical pathways between the camera and the at least one processor. Alternatively or additionally, the first channel and the second channel share a common electrical pathway between the camera and at least one processor configured to perform process 1500. For example, frame capture events associated with the first channel may be interleaved with frame capture events associated with the second channel. In some embodiments, the images received via the first channel may be captured by sampling a sensor associated with the camera during one or more time windows between image capture events associated with acquisition of the images received via the second channel, or vice versa. In some embodiments, the first channel and the second channel may be output channels of a sensor of the camera.

As described above, the first channel may be associated with a first frame capture rate, and the second channel may be associated with a second frame capture rate different from the first frame capture rate. In some embodiments, the first frame capture rate may be lower than the second frame capture rate. For example, the first frame capture may have a frequency of 18 Hz and the second frame capture rate may have a frequency of 30 Hz, however, various other suitable frequencies may be used. In some embodiments, the first frame capture rate may have a frequency configured to coincide with different amplitude levels (or light intensity levels) of an expected light-generation waveform associated with at least one of the flickering light sources. For example, the first frame capture rate may be associated with interval ib, as discussed above. As one example, the expected light generation waveform has a frequency between about 45 Hz and about 65 Hz, however, other suitable ranges may be used depending on a type of light source being detected. For example, the first frame capture rate may have a frequency that is a non-harmonic of a frequency of an expected light-generation waveform associated with at least one of the flickering light sources.

In some embodiments, the second frame capture rate may have a frequency configured to coincide with common amplitude levels (or light intensity levels) of an expected light-generation waveform associated with at least one of the flickering light sources. For example, the second frame capture rate may be associated with interval ia, as discussed above. Accordingly, the second frame capture rate may have a frequency that is a harmonic of a frequency of an expected light-generation waveform associated with at least one of the flickering light sources. In some embodiments, the frame capture rate may be adjusted, as described above. Accordingly, process 1500 may include adjusting at least one of the first frame capture rate or the second frame capture rate.

In some embodiments, an image capture event for the first channel and an image capture event for the second channel may align (or fall within a time window of each other), as described above. Accordingly, a single image may be captured to satisfy both image capture events. For example, at least a first image among the images received via the second channel (or the first channel) may be used both to provide the images for showing on the one or more human-viewable display and also for the detection of flickering and non-flickering light sources in the environment of the host vehicle.

Consistent with the embodiments of the present disclosure, the plurality of images may be captured in a burst of images (e.g., with a predetermined time window). For example, the first frame capture rate may be associated with a burst capture rate such that each image capture event associated with the first frame capture rate includes an acquisition of a burst of images. Each of the burst of images is associated with a different image sensor integration time. This may enable light intensity measurements for flickering and non-flickering light sources, as described above.

In step 1520, process 1500 includes using images received via the first channel to detect flickering and non-flickering light sources in an environment of the host vehicle. For example, light source detection component 1220 may detect flickering and non-flickering light sources using images received via channel 1222. As described above, the images received via the first channel may be used by at least one processor to detect AC-powered light sources and DC-powered light sources in the environment of the host vehicle. For example, AC-powered light sources may correspond to flickering light sources, whereas DC-powered light sources may be associated with non-flickering light sources.

In some embodiments, a vehicle may be configured to navigate based on detection of a flickering light source or non-flickering light source. For example, this may include navigating based on a traffic light, a brake light, a warning light, a street light, an emergency vehicle light, or the like. Accordingly, process 1500 may further include determining at least one navigational action for the host vehicle in response to detection of at least one flickering light source or detection of at least one non-flickering light source. The at least one navigational action may include at least one of braking of the host vehicle, accelerating the host vehicle, or changing a heading direction of the host vehicle, or various other navigation actions that may be performed by a vehicle.

In step 1530, process 1500 includes providing, based on images received via the second channel, images for showing on one or more human-viewable displays. For example, this may include displaying images received through channel 1232 on display device 1230, as described above. The one or more human-viewable displays may include any device configured to display images to a user, as described above. In some embodiments, the one or more human-viewable displays may include a heads-up display associated with the host vehicle.

In some embodiments, one or more properties of the images may be adjusted, for example, to improve detection of light sources, to improve viewability for a user, etc. Accordingly, process 1500 may further include adjusting an image sensor integration time of the camera to change integration times associated with acquisition of one or more of the images received via the first channel or the images received via the second channel. In some embodiments, the adjustment of the image sensor integration time is based on feedback. For example, the feedback may include a saturation level associated with a sensor of the camera. In some embodiments, the feedback may include a detected light intensity level of at least one of the flickering light sources or the non-flickering light sources in the environment of the host vehicle. As another example, the feedback may include a detected oscillation, frequency associated with at least one of the flickering light sources in the environment of the host vehicle.

In some embodiments, one or more of the first and second channels may be enabled or disabled as needed. For example, it may be more difficult, or perhaps less important to detect flickering and non-flickering light sources during daylight hours. Accordingly, images for channel 1222 may be disabled. As another example, if a user is not actively viewing images on the one or more human viewable displays, images for channel 1232 may be disabled. Disabling one of the first and second channels may reduce the demand on camera 1210 and may allow for better image quality or image capture rates for the enabled channel. Accordingly, process 1500 may include selectively enable and disable receipt of images via the first channel or via the second channel. For example, receipt of images via the first channel or via the second channel is selectively enabled and disabled based on a level of detected ambient light (which may be detected based on the plurality of images, or via separate sensor), based on a time of day, based on a geographic location (e.g., where no light sources are positioned), based on a user input, or the like. In some embodiments, receipt of images via the first channel may be selectively enabled at night and selectively disabled during the day.

The foregoing description has been presented for purposes of illustration. It is not exhaustive and is not limited to the precise forms or embodiments disclosed. Modifications and adaptations will be apparent to those skilled in the art from consideration of the specification and practice of the disclosed embodiments. Additionally, although aspects of the disclosed embodiments are described as being stored in memory, one skilled in the art will appreciate that these aspects can also be stored on other types of computer readable media, such as secondary storage devices, for example, hard disks or CD ROM, or other forms of RAM or ROM, USB media, DVD, Blu-ray, 4K Ultra HD Blu-ray, or other optical drive media.

Computer programs based on the written description and disclosed methods are within the skill of an experienced developer. The various programs or program modules can be created using any of the techniques known to one skilled in the art or can be designed in connection with existing software. For example, program sections or program modules can be designed in or by means of Net Framework, .Net Compact Framework (and related languages, such as Visual Basic, C, etc.), Java, C++, Objective-C, HTML. HTML/AJAX combinations. XML, or HTML with included Java applets.

Moreover, while illustrative embodiments have been described herein, the scope of any and all embodiments having equivalent elements, modifications, omissions, combinations (e.g., of aspects across various embodiments), adaptations and/or alterations as would be appreciated by those skilled in the art based on the present disclosure. The limitations in the claims are to be interpreted broadly based on the language employed in the claims and not limited to examples described in the present specification or during the prosecution of the application. The examples are to be construed as non-exclusive. Furthermore, the steps of the disclosed methods may be modified in any manner, including by reordering steps and/or inserting or deleting steps. It is intended, therefore, that the specification and examples be considered as illustrative only, with a true scope and spirit being indicated by the following claims and their full scope of equivalents.

claim.claim-text: 1. A system for a host vehicle, the system comprising:at least one processor comprising circuitry and a memory, wherein the memory includes instructions that when executed by the circuitry cause the at least one processor to:receive a plurality of images acquired by a camera onboard the host vehicle, wherein the plurality of images are received via a first channel and via a second channel, and wherein the first channel is associated with a first frame capture rate, and the second channel is associated with a second frame capture rate different from the first frame capture rate;use images received via the first channel to detect flickering and non-flickering light sources in an environment of the host vehicle; andprovide, based on images received via the second channel, images for showing on one or more human-viewable displays.

2. The system of claim 1, wherein the memory includes instructions that when executed by the circuitry cause the at least one processor to determine at least one navigational action for the host vehicle in response to detection of at least one flickering light source or detection of at least one non-flickering light source.

3. The system of claim 2, wherein the at least one navigational action includes at least one of braking of the host vehicle, accelerating the host vehicle, or changing a heading direction of the host vehicle.
4. The system of claim 1, wherein the first channel and the second channel are associated with different electrical pathways between the camera and the at least one processor.
5. The system of claim 1, wherein the first channel and the second channel share a common electrical pathway between the camera and the at least one processor.
6. The system of claim 5, wherein frame capture events associated with the first channel are interleaved with frame capture events associated with the second channel.
7. The system of claim 1, wherein the first frame capture rate is lower than the second frame capture rate.
8. The system of claim 7, wherein the first frame capture has a frequency of 1K Hz and the second frame capture rate has a frequency of 30 Hz.

9. The system of claim 1, wherein the first frame capture rate has a frequency configured to coincide with different amplitude levels of an expected light-generation waveform associated with at least one of the flickering light sources.
10. The system of claim 9, wherein the expected light-generation waveform has a frequency between about 45 Hz and about 65 Hz.

11. The system of claim 1, wherein the second frame capture rate has a frequency configured to coincide with common amplitude levels of an expected light-generation waveform associated with at least one of the flickering light sources.

12. The system of claim 1, wherein the first frame capture rate has a frequency configured to enable sampling different light intensity levels of an expected light-generation waveform associated with at least one of the flickering light sources.

13. The system of claim 1, wherein the second frame capture rate has a frequency configured to enable sampling of constant light intensity levels of an expected light-generation waveform associated with at least one of the flickering light sources.

14. The system of claim 1, wherein the first frame capture rate has a frequency that is a non-harmonic of a frequency of an expected light-generation waveform associated with at least one of the flickering light sources.

15. The system of claim 1, wherein the second frame capture rate has a frequency that is a harmonic of a frequency of an expected light-generation waveform associated with at least one of the flickering light sources.

16. The system of claim 1, wherein the images received via the first channel are used by the at least one processor to detect AC-powered light sources and DC-powered light sources in the environment of the host vehicle.
17. The system of claim 1, wherein the one or more human-viewable displays include a heads-up display associated with the host vehicle.

18. The system of claim 1, wherein the memory includes instructions that when executed by the circuitry cause the at least one processor to selectively enable and disable receipt of images via the first channel or via the second channel.
19. The system of claim 18, wherein receipt of images via the first channel or via the second channel is selectively enabled and disabled based on a level of detected ambient light.
20. The system of claim 18, wherein receipt of images via the first channel or via the second channel is selectively enabled and disabled based on a time of day.
21. The system of claim 18, wherein receipt of images via the first channel is selectively enabled at night and selectively disabled during the day.

22. The system of claim 1, wherein the memory includes instructions that when executed by the circuitry cause the at least one processor to adjust an image sensor integration time of the camera to change integration times associated with acquisition of one or more of the images received via the first channel or the images received via the second channel.
23. The system of claim 22, wherein the adjustment of the image sensor integration time is based on feedback.
24. The system of claim 23, wherein the feedback includes a saturation level associated with a sensor of the camera.

25. The system of claim 23, wherein the feedback includes a detected light intensity level of at least one of the flickering light sources or the non-flickering light sources in the environment of the host vehicle
26. The system of claim 23, wherein the feedback includes a detected oscillation, frequency associated with at least one of the flickering light sources in the environment of the host vehicle.

27. The system of claim 1, wherein the images received via the first channel are captured by sampling a sensor associated with the camera during one or more time windows between image capture events associated with acquisition of the images received via the second channel.

28. The system of claim 1, wherein the memory includes instructions that when executed by the circuitry cause the at least one processor to adjust at least one of the first frame capture rate or the second frame capture rate.

29. The system of claim 1, wherein at least a first image among the images received via the second channel is used both to provide the images for showing on the one or more human-viewable display and also for the detection of flickering and non-flickering light sources in the environment of the host vehicle.

30. The system of claim 1, wherein the first frame capture rate is associated with a burst capture rate such that each image capture event associated with the first frame capture rate includes an acquisition of a burst of images.
31. The system of claim 30, wherein each of the burst of images is associated with a different image sensor integration time.
32. The system of claim 1, wherein the first channel and the second channel are output channels of a sensor of the camera.

33. A method, the method comprising:receiving a plurality of images acquired by a camera onboard a host vehicle, wherein the plurality of images are received via a first channel and via a second channel, and wherein the first channel is associated with a first frame capture rate, and the second channel is associated with a second frame capture rate different from the first frame capture rate;using images received via the first channel to detect flickering and non-flickering light sources in an environment of the host vehicle; andproviding, based on images received via the second channel, images for showing on one or more human-viewable displays.

34. A non-transitory computer readable medium containing instructions that when executed by at least one processor, cause the at least one processor to perform a method, the method comprising:receiving a plurality of images acquired by a camera onboard a host vehicle, wherein the plurality of images are received via a first channel and via a second channel, and wherein the first channel is associated with a first frame capture rate, and the second channel is associated with a second frame capture rate different from the first frame capture rate;using images received via the first channel to detect flickering and non-flickering light sources in an environment of the host vehicle; andproviding, based on images received via the second channel, images for showing on one or more human-viewable displays.
